CONFIG.general_instructions: This project is an AI assistant for a course. The output of each request must be a response that guides a student in understanding a topic.
CONFIG.description:
The Data and AI Intensive Research with Rigor and Reproducibility (DAIR-3) program is funded by Award 5R25GM151182 of the National Institute of General Medical Sciences, one of the 27 institutes of the National Institutes of Health of the United States. The principal investigators are Jing Liu (University of Michigan) and Juan B. GutiÃ©rrez (University of Texas at San Antonio). 
The rigor of scientific research and the reproducibility of research results are essential for the validity of research findings and the trustworthiness of science. However, research rigor and reproducibility remains a significant challenge across scientific fields, especially for research with complex data types from heterogeneous sources, and long data manipulation pipelines. This is especially critical as data science and artificial intelligence (AI) methods emerge at lightning speed and researchers scramble to seize the opportunities that the new methods bring.  

While researchers recognize the importance of rigor and reproducibility, they often lack the resources and the technical know-how to achieve this consistently in practice. With funding from the National Institutes of Health, a multi-university team offers a nationwide program to equip faculty and technical staff in biomedical sciences with the skills needed to improve the rigor and reproducibility of their research, and help them transfer such skills to their trainees. 

Trainees will then be guided over a one-year period to incorporate the newly acquired mindset, skills and tools into their research; and develop training for their own institutions.  

The DAIR3 team and instructors include faculty and staff research leaders from the University of Michigan, the College of William and Mary, Jackson State University, and University of Texas San Antonio. This highly diverse team will model the culture of diversity that we promote, and will support trainees who are demographically, professionally and scientifically diverse, and are from a diverse range of institutions, including those with limited resources.

knowledgeBase.summary: (meta)data meet domain -relevant community standardsFAIR Data –Conclusion ●Data built and disseminated to be findable, accessible, interoperable,  and reusable are best positioned to maximize the benefits of data  sharing and minimize the costs NIH PoliciesNIH Policies Several policies apply to all NIH -funded research since 2023: -Data Management & Sharing -Genomic Data -Model Organisms -Research Tools -Clinical Trials Dissemination Some institutes and centers have their own requirements and repositories as well https://sharing.nih.gov/other -sharing -policies/which -policies -apply -to-my-research NIH Data Management and Sharing Policy The NIH Policy for Data Management & Sharing  came into effect in 2023, requiring that  researchers: ●Plan and budget for data management and sharing  ●Submit a 2 -page DMS plan with each proposal ●Comply with and report on approved DMS plan https://sharing.nih.gov/other -sharing -policies/which -policies -apply -to-my-research RepositoriesNIH Guidance:  Which repository is best for your research? Domain -specific repositories would generally have more detailed metadata than generalist repositories.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Curation & Quality Assurance https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Provides, or has a mechanism for others to provide, expert curation and quality assurance to improve the accuracy and integrity of datasets and metadata.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Free & Easy Access https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Provides broad, equitable, and maximally open access to datasets and their metadata free of charge in a timely manner after submission, consistent with legal and ethical limits required to maintain privacy and confidentiality, Tribal sovereignty, and protection of other sensitive data.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Broad & Measured Reuse https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Makes datasets and their metadata available with broadest possible terms of reuse; and provides the ability to measure attribution, citation, and reuse of data (i.e., through assignment of adequate metadata and unique PIDs).” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Clear Use Guidance https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Provides accompanying documentation describing terms of dataset access and use (e.g., particular licenses, need for approval by a data use committee).” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Security and Integrity https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repositoryHas documented measures in place to meet generally accepted criteria for preventing unauthorized access to, modification of, or release of data, with levels of security that are appropriate to the sensitivity of data.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Confidentiality https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Has documented capabilities for ensuring that administrative, technical, and physical safeguards are employed to comply with applicable confidentiality, risk management, and continuous monitoring requirements for sensitive data.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Common Format  https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Allows datasets and metadata downloaded, accessed, or exported from the repository to be in widely used, preferably non -proprietary, formats consistent with those used in the community( ies) the repository serves.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Provenance https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Has mechanisms in place to record the origin, chain of custody, and any modifications to submitted datasets and metadata.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Retention Policy https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Provides documentation on policies for data retention within the repository.” NIH Guidance on Repository Selection Download Control  https://sharing.nih.gov/data -management -and-sharing -policy/sharing -scientific -data/selecting -a-data -repository“Controls and audits access to and download of datasets (if download is permitted).” Domain -specific repositories  The NIH BioMedical Informatics Coordinating Committee maintains a list of domain - specific and NIH -supported repositories, of which there are currently 147.

knowledgeBase.summary: Reasons that are NOT justifiable include: ●Data considered to be too small ●Data researchers anticipate will not be widely used ●No suitable repository The Tension Transparency Patient privacy5 “Safes” Framework of sensitive data •Maximize data sharing AND  •Preserve confidentiality 5 “Safes” Framework: PROJECTS Safe projects capture the: Legal Ethical Regulatory for a given use of the data ❖IRB Projects People Data  Outputs Settings 5 “Safes” Framework:  PEOPLE “Safe People” addresses the  trustworthiness of the research  team using the data: Training Attestation ❖Professional Responsibility Projects People Data  Outputs Settings 5 “Safes” Framework:  DATA “Safe Data” examines the risks of  the info contained in the data: personal identifiers crosswalk ❖Minimum Necessary Projects People Data  Outputs Settings 5 “Safes” Framework:  OUTPUTS “Safe Outputs” highlights the  stage between analyses and  public release of information  Cell size limitations Disclosure review ❖Re-Identification Risk Projects People Data  Outputs Settings 5 “Safes” Framework:  SETTINGS “Safe Settings” refers to the  physical and IT security of the  research data  Secure logins Encryption Physical enclaves ❖Compliant Storage Projects People Data  Outputs Settings Different Types of  BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH Sharing Data:  animal models Title:  Parietal Cortex and the Transformation of Spatial Cognition into Action PI:  Douglas Nitz Funder: NSF Sharing: Policies for access and sharing All data, metadata, and analyses collected under the proposed experiments will be  made publicly available as per NSF guidelines within 2 years of collection via published manuscripts , publicly  available final reports to NSF, and/or from data archives at UCSD’s Department of Cognitive Science. All tiers of data require a data -use  agreemen t at a minimum, additional precautions for restricted -use, high restricted -use, and virtual  enclave data will be included in the data request forms Linkage –opportunities •Linkage of data across disparate sources offers  full picture of the patient , research participant  JACKSON HEART STUDY Linkage allows  investigators to  understand all the  contributors to  wellness, illness Linkage –opportunities  Linkage –cautions •Linkage or triangulation of data could lead to  identifiability/breach of privacy Single “de - identified”  Data Set Increasingly  identifiable  w/new data  sources  Linkage –cautions Human subjects research: •AI:  large language models •Awareness of external linkages, commercial  platforms  Questions for Today: •What is the role of IRB?
